Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
April 28, 2025. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action
plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of the exit
conference and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result in
compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the corrective
action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager Samantha Way at 517-243-9743.
Sincerely,

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CCI Rule 400.4111 Job description
(1) An institution shall provide a job description for
each staff position that identifies rules, required
qualifications, and lines of authority.
One of twenty new employee files did not have verification the employee received
their job description.
2

CCI Rule 400.4113 Employee records.
(1) An institution shall maintain employee records
for each employee and shall include
documentation of all of the following information
prior to employment or at the time specified in
this rule:
(i) Documentation from the Michigan
department of human services, the
equivalent state or Canadian provincial
agency, or equivalent agency in the
country where the person usually resides,
that the person has not been determined
to be a perpetrator of child abuse or child
neglect. The documentation shall be
completed not more than 30 days prior to
the start of employment and every 12
months thereafter.
Two of twenty new employee files did not have a central registry clearance
completed within 30 days prior to hire.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Renewal Inspection Report dated 3/27/24; CAP approved 4/25/24
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The agency was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• For youth discharged from the program - a case transfer summary alone isn't
sufficient. If they leave the program, there must be a discharge report.
• Central Registry clearance checks not being completed within 30 days prior to
hire has been a violation for the past 4 annual audits (including this one). This
is a serious issue as it directly relates to the safety of the youth cared for by
the facility. This violation cannot happen again and there needs to be many
levels of oversight and signoffs to occur prior to anyone getting hired
(especially if delaying a hire date).
• The new hire checklist should say "CANS checks within 30 days prior to hire"
instead of "within 30 days of hire" to ensure clarity.
• The facility must create and follow a uniform process for employee records to
ensure all the information required by licensing rules is in the employee's file,
especially at the time of the facility's annual audit. The electronic files
provided by HR were missing multiple documents. It doesn't matter if the HR
file come from the program directly or HR, but the file provided must include
all required documents.
• The facility did not provide an accurate employee list which caused 7 new
employee files not to be reviewed during the first round of reviews. It wasn't
3

until the Consultant asked further questions that the additional information
was provided. It is imperative the employee list provided during annual audits
includes names, position and hire dates for all employees during the period of
review. Any employees missed in the future will likely result in automatic
violations for licensing rules related to employee records.
V. CONSULTATION
The agency was offered consultation in the following areas:
• Hire Date, Employee name and Supervisor name should be listed on the new
hire checklist to verify the date of hire, which employee it's for and the hiring
manager signing off on the information.
• Hire Dates on the staff audit lists provided to the Consultant need to be
double-checked as there were two incorrect hire dates listed, which caused
confusion when verifying timeframes for hire documents.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
Maltreatment in Care
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 2 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows: The first
CAP was a result of the facility's 2024 Renewal inspection assessment. The
facility had the following violations and addressed them in the following ways:
- Rule 4113(1)(i) - The facility updated the new hire checklist to reflect the
central registry check must be within 30 days prior to hire, completed
updated central registry checks for staff who didn't have them, created an
all-staff spreadsheet where dates of annual background checks and
training would be maintained to ensure compliance, and committed to
completing multi-levels of review of background checks prior to hire.
- Rule 4113(1)(e) - The facility completed updated references for the staff
whose references were over 12 months old, updated the new hire
checklist to reflect the reference requirement, and required the Quality
Assurance specialist to sign off on the new hire checklist prior to hire.
- Rule 4114(1) - The facility completed updated TB testing for the staff
whose TB test was over 12 months old and updated the new hire
checklist to reflect the TB testing requirement.
- Rule 4142(1)(d) - The facility reviewed the storage of medications policy
with staff, supervisors completed unannounced weekly checks to ensure
4

the medication cart was locked and committed to reviewing the
medication storage policy quarterly at staff meetings.
- Rule 4159(1)(d) - The facility committed to listing CPI training on the
newly created all staff spreadsheet to track CPI training dates and
required the Quality Assurance Coordinator review the spreadsheet and
follow-up with staff/supervisors regarding registration and attendance.
- Rule 4167(1) and (2) - The facility created a documentation training for
case management staff, reviewed file record requirements during staff
meetings, and implemented new case review requirements for youth
files.
- Rule 4166(1)(a-f) - The facility reviewed discharge expectations with staff
during staff meetings and implemented a new case file review process
for discharged youth.
The second CAP was a result of SIR #2025SIC0000019. The facility had the
following violations and addressed them in the following ways:
- Rule 4127(4) - The facility completed trainings on the AWOL procedures
and line of sight policy with staff on a quarterly basis, unit supervisors
discussed task assignments and delegation with youth specialists during
staff trainings/meetings, and staff on-call expectations were updated.
- Rule 4150(3) - The facility committed to implementing an on-call bi-
monthly meeting to review on-call expectations and any policy
updates/changes and created an outline regarding DCWL notification
requirements and reviewed it at the on-call bi-monthly meeting.
Financial Overview
There were no financial concerns based on review of the facility's budget and
financial audit.
PREA compliance (if applicable)
Not Applicable
Chief Administrator Assessment
Chief Administrator (CA) reported the Quality Assurance (QA) team has been
reviewing staff files prior to hire to ensure the central registry clearance is
completed as required. In addition, hiring managers are now required to complete
Bethany's New Hiring Manager Training to ensure they understand the
expectations and requirements for the hiring process. CA reported shelter
supervisors are checking the medication cart daily during their unannounced round
to ensure the medication cart is always locked. CA reported the QA team has been
reviewing the all-staff spreadsheet at least weekly or every other week to ensure
staff are up to date with CPI training and it's documented on the spreadsheet. CA
reported case management supervisors have been reviewing due dates for service
5

plans and signatures on a weekly basis to ensure compliance. CA reported staff
files have been a hardship for the team as the hiring happens at a program level,
not at a human resources level. CA reported some supervisors were not properly
trained, and sometimes requirements changed, but not all hiring managers
received the updated information. CA reported the quality assurance team
continues to work with hiring managers and human resources to ensure
compliance. CA reported program supervisors put hiring updates on their meeting
agenda to discuss changes, and they review hiring expectations at least quarterly.
CA reported staff meetings occur weekly, which include updates for the program as
well as policy and procedure reviews.
Staff and Youth Interviews
On 4/28/25, Assistant Program directors reported it had been approximately 2
months since they last had youth admitted to the program. They reported referrals
have been lacking, and when referrals come in, other agencies quickly accept
those referrals. They reported the lack of youth in the program has allowed them
the space and time to revamp systems, organizational tools & tactics, and offer
intentional training for staff. They reported they have updated shelter process,
youth files, file review process, and closed file process. They reported they have
also offered a lot of staff activities to keep staff engaged and morale high in the
program while there aren't youth admitted. They reported it's been a breath of fresh
air to have some time to think without the chaos and use the time to decompress.
They reported they have continued to work on determining appropriate resources
for staff. They reported there are very transparent conversations happening from
upper administration, which feels really positive. The Director is setting the stage
for "we are all in the same boat" which has been well-received by staff. They
reported teachers are getting creative with how to utilize their time, including staff
training and education, especially with offering ESL (English as a Second
Language) classes and Spanish classes. They reported they have also encouraged
all staff to sign up for the MDHHS weekly emails and have found great free
trainings for staff through that resource.
The facility does not currently have any youth admitted due to a lack of referrals.
Description of Agency Walk Through
A walkthrough of the facility occurred on 4/28/25 and there were no concerns
noted.

VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is
recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
